save_chapter_1_intro: Rente kan een grote invloed hebben op onze persoonlijke financiën, maar het concept is tamelijk moeilijk te begrijpen. In deze sessie introduceer je het concept door het gebruik van een klein snoepje as metafoor. Je kunt dan doorgaan met uit te leggen hoe het bij geld werkt en hoe de spaarbonus in de app werkt.
save_chapter_1_desc: Introduceer het concept van rente door gebruik te maken van een klein snoepje.
save_chapter_1_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE With younger children encourage the idea of saving on a regular basis, they may be able to understand the idea of interest – but keep it very simple.
save_chapter_1_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Recognise what interest is 
Understand the benefits of saving 
Appreciate that planning, spending, and saving enables you to manage your money
save_chapter_1_step_1_desc: Geef je kind een snoepje en zeg: 'Eet dit snoepje nu niet op maar wacht 1 uur en dan krijg je er nog een'.
save_chapter_1_step_2_desc: Leg uit dat rente krijgen is als het krijgen van nog een snoepje. Als jij je geld spaart dan krijg je meer.
save_chapter_1_step_3_desc: 'Voor elke €10 die je spaart, krijg je nog eens 10c op Payday'
save_chapter_2_intro: Geld sparen is ons bewust zijn van hoe we het uitgeven. Maar uit gewoonte gooien we vaak onze zuur verdiende centen weg zonder dat we ons dat echt realiseren. Terwijl €3 uitgeven voor een chocolade reep op zaterdagavond niet zoveel lijkt, als je dat elke week doet is het samen een klein fortuin. In deze sessie, daag jij je gezin uit om voor een leuke gezins-activiteit te sparen door te bezuinigen op niet noodzakelijke uitgaven.
save_chapter_2_desc: Spaar voor een gezins-activiteit door minder te snoepen
save_chapter_2_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE With younger children you might do this as an individual task, picking something relatively inexpensive to save for at first. It might also be easier for them to save first and then decide what to do with the saved.
save_chapter_2_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Starting to understand simple financial planning 
Be able to explain some of the benefits of saving 
Appreciate how changing our habits may help us save
save_chapter_2_step_1_desc: Wordt het eens over een leuke gezins-activiteit die jullie willen doen en zoek uit wat dat gaat kosten.
save_chapter_2_step_2_desc: Deel de kosten van je doel door de wekelijkse uitgaven voor snoep. Zolang zul je moeten verminderen
save_chapter_2_step_3_desc: Laat iedereen bijdragen, en hou je vorderingen bij door het elke week op je kalender te markeren.
save_chapter_3_intro: Zuinig zijn lijkt misschien een verwaarloosbare spaarstrategie, maar als het toegepast wordt op artikelen die je elke dag gebruikt dan kan het in de loop van de tijd een fortuin worden. Als we zuinig zijn dan moeten we altijd de balans zoeken tussen prijs en kwaliteit. Je kunt misschien €50 per jaar sparen door te wisselen naar goedkoper toiletpapier. Maar dat betekent misschien ook dat je wellicht genoegen moet nemen met minder kwaliteit. Is dat zo? En is het dat dan waard?
save_chapter_3_desc: Vergelijk toiletpapier en overleg of zuinigheid hier op zijn plaats is.
save_chapter_3_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE Younger children will need support. Use products that can be tasted e.g. cereals (own brand versus branded products)”
save_chapter_3_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Understand that some things are better value for money than others 
Be able to make comparisons between different products and prices 
Appreciate that other people may have different ideas about spending money
save_chapter_3_step_1_desc: Zoek naar het goedkoopste en het duurste toiletpapier door te kijken naar de prijs per meter.
save_chapter_3_step_2_desc: Probeer het duurste toiletpapier dat je kunt vinden
save_chapter_3_step_3_desc: Als het dure toiletpapier op is, wissel dan naar het goedkope toiletpapier.
save_chapter_3_step_4_desc: Hoeveel bespaar je per jaar als je het goedkope in plaats van het dure toiletpapier zou kopen?
save_chapter_3_step_5_desc: Is het dure toiletpapier de extra uitgaven waard? Of wil je liever zuinig zijn en geld besparen?
earn_chapter_1_intro: Geld verdienen is in principe het vinden van oplossingen voor problemen waar iemand anders voor wil betalen. Neem, bijvoorbeeld, een kapper. Zij/hij zou geen geld verdienen als er geen mensen zouden zijn die het waard vinden om geknipt te worden. In deze sessie, daag jij je kind uit om te oefenen in het oplossen van problemen. Je ziet problemen rondom het huis, suggereert oplossingen en onderhandelt over de beloning.
earn_chapter_1_desc: Identificeer en los problemen op rondom het huis.
earn_chapter_1_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE With younger children, identify simple tasks like clearing away toys. You could also share or work on tasks together
earn_chapter_1_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Understand that we earn money doing jobs 
Be able to identify different types of jobs and tasks to be done around the house 
Appreciate that some jobs may earn more than others
earn_chapter_1_step_1_desc: Maak een lijst met problemen rondom het huis. Is het gazon overwoekerd? Beginnen de planten er droevig uit te zien?
earn_chapter_1_step_2_desc: Probeer een oplossing te vinden voor elk probleem op je lijst.
earn_chapter_1_step_3_desc: Welke problemen op je lijst zijn het waard om voor de oplossing ervan te betalen? En voor hoeveel?
earn_chapter_1_step_4_desc: Wijs klusjes toe in de app, of laat je kind ze suggereren.
earn_chapter_2_intro: Geld verdienen wordt normaal geassocieerd met een baan hebben. Maar dat is geen noodzaak. Sommigen verdienen hun geld als ondernemer. Een ondernemer is iemand die tijd en geld investeert in het opzetten en leiden van een bedrijf. Als het succesvol is dan verdient zij/hij meer geld dan er was geïnvesteerd. Zo niet, dan kan het geïnvesteerde geld verloren gaan.
earn_chapter_2_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE With younger children identify a simple craft item they could make, like decorated fridge magnets.
earn_chapter_2_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Understand that we can earn money by working, including running our own business 
Be able to identify different opportunities to make and sell things 
Appreciate that businesses need investment and you may lose money as well as make it
earn_chapter_2_step_1_desc: Verzamel wat je nodig hebt om je koekjes bedrijf te runnen, zoals ingrediënten.
earn_chapter_2_step_2_desc: Laat mensen weten dat je koekjes verkoopt. Laat ze ook weten waar en wanneer ze verkrijgbaar zijn.
earn_chapter_2_step_3_desc: Het is een goed idee om bij te houden hoeveel je hebt uitgegeven en hoeveel je hebt verdiend
earn_chapter_2_step_4_desc: Na een dag of een week, verminder het verdiende geld met het uitgegeven geld. Heb je winst of verlies gemaakt?
earn_chapter_2_step_5_desc: Als je winst maakt, stort het geld dan op de spaarrekening van je kind.
earn_chapter_3_intro: Oude spullen, die we niet meer gebruiken, verkopen is niet alleen een prima manier om ons huis op te ruimen, maar ook een manier om wat extra geld te verdienen. Alleen omdat jij iets niet meer gebruik wil dat niet zeggen dat iemand anders dat niet doet. Laat het om te beginnen een les voor je zijn als je er niet zoveel krijgt als jezelf betaald had, je denkt twee keer na voordat je de volgende keer iets vergelijkbaars koopt.
earn_chapter_3_desc: Maak je huis schoon en verkoop spullen die je niet meer gebruikt.
earn_chapter_3_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE Younger children will need more support to identify things that they no longer want or need. It will be important to ensure that they understand that selling it will mean it is no longer theirs.
earn_chapter_3_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Understand that we can make money from selling unwanted items 
Be able to identify items they no longer need or want 
Appreciate that our unwanted items may have a value to others
earn_chapter_3_step_1_desc: Terwijl je schoonmaakt, probeer spullen te vinden die je niet meer gebruikt.
earn_chapter_3_step_2_desc: Ga bij een kofferbak verkoop of verkoop je niet gebruikte spullen online. Doneer onverkoopbare spullen aan een goed doel.
earn_chapter_3_step_3_desc: Hoeveel heb je om te beginnen voor alles betaald? Was dat het waard nu je weet voor hoeveel je het hebt verkocht?
spend_chapter_1_intro: Om ons geld verstandig uit te geven moeten we leren prioriteiten te stellen voor wat nodig is in het leven en wat leuk is om te hebben. Maar dat is niet altijd duidelijk. Op het eerste gezicht lijken snacks essentieel voor een vrijdagavond. Maar misschien toch niet als dat betekent geen tandpasta. Want als je dat doet, dan kan dit betekenen dat je in de toekomst veel meer gaat betalen voor je tandheelkundige zorg. In deze sessie, daag jij je kind uit een boodschappenlijst te maken door een balans te bereiken tussen behoeften en wensen van je gezin.
spend_chapter_1_desc: Maak een booschappenlijst en vind een balans tussen behoeften & wensen.
spend_chapter_1_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE With older children allow them to take more responsibility for a bigger family shop – work together to decide what will be needed for the week, can they identify things that are wants rather than needs?
spend_chapter_1_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Understand the difference between a need and a want 
Know that they have choices about spending money 
Appreciate that people may make different choices to their own
spend_chapter_1_step_1_desc: Maak een lijst van artikelen die je regelmatig koopt en voeg een aantal speciale aankopen toe.
spend_chapter_1_step_2_desc: Verdeel de artikelen op je lijst in wat je gezin nodig heeft, en wat je wilt maar waar je zonder kunt.
spend_chapter_1_step_3_desc: Probeer je lijst tot de helft van de artikelen te beperken. Motiveer je keuzes op basis van behoeften en wensen.
spend_chapter_1_step_4_desc: Ga samen boodschappen doen. Zorg ervoor dat je vasthoudt aan je nieuwe lijst!
spend_chapter_2_intro: Binnen budget blijven is een noodzakelijke vaardigheid voor volwassenen, maar het kan een harde les zijn om te leren. Je kunt gemakkelijk meegesleept worden bij het uitgeven. Kinderen uitdagen om beslissingen te nemen over een bepaalde hoeveelheid geld, is niet alleen een goede oefening in budgetteren, maar helpt ze ook begrijpen hoeveel iets echt kost.
spend_chapter_2_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE Younger children will be able to participate with support. Try allocating just one element of the task to them e.g. the cost of food for the trip or finding out the cost of the entrance tickets.
spend_chapter_2_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Know how to use simple financial information to plan and make a simple budget 
Understand that planning, spending helps stay in control of money 
Appreciate the need to take other people’s ideas into account when making decisions about spending money
spend_chapter_2_step_1_desc: Laat elk gezinslid ideëen opnoemen voor activiteiten die je kunt doen voor €30.
spend_chapter_2_step_2_desc: Zoek de echte kosten van elke idee uit. Zorg ervoor rekening te houden met kosten zoals vervoer en eten.
spend_chapter_2_step_3_desc: Kom tot een akkoord over een activiteit en maak er een budget voor. Zorg ervoor dat je niet over de €30 gaat.
spend_chapter_2_step_4_desc: Bewaar alle bonnetjes en vergelijk ze met je budget. Heb je meer of minder uitgegeven?
spend_chapter_3_intro: Om geld verstandig uit te geven, moeten we leren om beslissingen te nemen gebaseerd op wat belangrijk is voor ons. Maar dat is niet altijd duidelijk. Is 't het waard om €50 te betalen voor een paar schoenen als er ook schoenen voor €10 zijn? Misschien niet. Maar aan de andere kant, wat als de duurdere schoenen je beter passen en ze veel warmer zijn?
spend_chapter_3_desc: Maak een koopbeslissing gebaseerd op belangrijke kenmerken.
spend_chapter_3_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE Younger children could participate with additional support – keep choices simple.
spend_chapter_3_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Understand that making informed decisions will help them make the most of their money 
Appreciate that being a critical consumer involves using information to make a choice 
Know that decisions they make can be influenced by others
spend_chapter_3_step_1_desc: Vraag je kind om 2 paar schoenen uit te zoeken, binnen je budget, die zij/hij leuk vindt.
spend_chapter_3_step_2_desc: Bedenk tenminste 3 kenmerken die belangrijk zijn voor de aankoop, zoals design, kwaliteit en comfort.
spend_chapter_3_step_3_desc: Gebruik je criteria om de schoenen te vergelijken: 'Dit paar heeft een mooier design en betere kwaliteit maar is niet zo comfortabel'.
spend_chapter_3_step_4_desc: Kom tot een akkoord welke schoenen te kopen gebaseerd op hoe goed ze aan jouw criteria voldoen.
about_gimi_education_section_1: Met sessies, een verzameling activiteiten, leren gezinnen hun jonge kinderen alles over geld.
about_gimi_education_section_2: Elke activiteit is onderverdeeld in stappen, volg ze en markeer de activiteit als af als ze voltooid is. We gebruiken voorbeelden om de activiteiten tastbaarder te maken. Passen ze niet bij je gezin? Voel je dan vrij om ze aan te passen!
about_gimi_education_section_3: Onderzoek suggereert dat kinderen goede geldgewoonten leren en slim met geld omgaan door betrokken te zijn bij gezinsfinanciën en gesprekken over geld. Samen oefenen met geldbeheer geeft kinderen de kans om vaardigheden te leren die nodig zijn om in de toekomst zelf goed geïnformeerde financiële beslissingen te nemen, of het nu gaat om het verdienen, sparen of uitgeven van geld.
save_chapter_4: PLZ_TRANSLATE Start saving for a goal
save_chapter_4_intro: Geld sparen is een van de meest belangrijke lessen in het leven die je moet leren, en om te leren moeten we oefenen. Maar soms is het moeilijk en weet je niet hoe je moet beginnen. In deze sessie help jij je kind een droomwens te vinden waarvoor gespaard wordt.
save_chapter_4_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Find a goal that motivates your child to start saving for
save_chapter_4_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE For older children choose more expensive options and save for longer. Think of other ways they can save up.
save_chapter_4_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Know the difference between things they need and things they want 
Be able to describe why they want to save money 
Be able to make simple saving choices
save_chapter_4_step_1_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Ask your child to list everything he or she wants to buy but can’t afford right now.
save_chapter_4_step_2_desc: Sorteer de lijst op wat belangrijk lijkt naar het minst belangrijk.
save_chapter_4_step_3_desc: Schat hoe lang het zal duren om te sparen voor het belangrijkste op de lijst.
save_chapter_4_step_4_desc: Is er een kans dat gedurende die tijd de prioriteiten veranderen? Wil het kind liever voor iets anders sparen?
save_chapter_4_step_5_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Ask the child to create a goal in the app and make a plan for reaching it together.
earn_chapter_4_intro: Iets doen dat we graag doen en waar we goed in zijn maakt werk normaal leuker. Maar het kan moeilijk zijn om te weten wat dat iets is. Een manier om daar achter te komen is onze interesses verkennen en vaardigheden op deze gebieden te ontwikkelen. In deze sessie daag jij je kind uit om na te denken over zijn of haar interesses en een manier te vinden om vaardigheden op deze gebieden te ontwikkelen.
earn_chapter_4_desc: Verken interesses en ontwikkel vaardigheden binnen deze gebieden
earn_chapter_4_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE With younger children you could practice basic skills that could be used in many different jobs. E.g. typing on a keyboard
earn_chapter_4_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Know that there are a range of different jobs and that working is one way we can earn money 
Understand that some jobs will require specific skills and knowledge 
Appreciate that the choices they make about work in the future might affect how much they earn
earn_chapter_4_step_1_desc: Vraag het kind op te schrijven wat zijn of haar interesses zijn of wat hij of zij graag doet.
earn_chapter_4_step_2_desc: Vind banen gerelateerd aan de interesses op de lijst. Een interesse in eten kan leiden tot een loopbaan als kok?
earn_chapter_4_step_3_desc: Zoek manieren om de banen te oefenen. De eerste stap om een kok te worden kan zijn om het avondeten voor zondag klaar te maken?
spend_chapter_4_intro: Leren om duurzaam uit te geven is belangrijk. Niet alleen voor onze portemonnees, maar ook voor onze planeet. Een goed begin is nadenken over de drie R's: Reduce (Verminderen), Reuse (hergebruiken), Recycle.
spend_chapter_4_desc: Praat erover hoe jouw gezin meer duurzaam kan uitgeven.
spend_chapter_4_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE With older children - give them a personal 3 R’s challenge.
spend_chapter_4_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Know that they have choices about spending and saving money and these are linked to our needs and wants 
Understand that the choices they make can have an impact on others, including our environment 
Recognise products that can be recycled or might not be so environmentally friendly
spend_chapter_4_step_1_desc: Wordt het eens over de aankopen van je gezin die minder kunnen. Artikelen die je vaak koopt maar niet echt nodig hebt?
spend_chapter_4_step_2_desc: Wordt het eens over wat je gezin kan huren of tweedehands kopen in plaats van gloednieuw te kopen.
spend_chapter_4_step_3_desc: Wordt het eens over wat je gezin koopt dat recycelbaar zou moeten zijn.
spend_chapter_4_step_4_desc: Schrijf alles op waar je het overeens bent en laat elk gezinslid het akkoord tekenen.
spend_chapter_5_intro: Deze sessie is voor ouders die hun kinderen willen helpen met de eerste aankoop, met de kaart, in een winkel.
spend_chapter_5_desc: Help je kind met de eerste betaling met de nieuwe Gimi-kaart
spend_chapter_5_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE With younger children practice paying with cash – learning about change and using receipts to keep track of their spending.
spend_chapter_5_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Know that cash is not the only way to pay 
Understand the importance of checking basic financial information e.g. receipts; card balances etc. 
Appreciate that it is important to keep money and personal information safe
spend_chapter_5_step_1_desc: Leg uit dat om te kunnen betalen er voldoende geld op de kaart moet staan. Vraag je kind om het saldo te controleren.
spend_chapter_5_step_2_desc: Vertel je kind om het bedrag op de betaalautomaat te controleren en de kaart erin te steken of erlangs te bewegen. Tik, indien nodig, de pincode in.
spend_chapter_5_step_3_desc: Leg uit dat je de kassabon moet bewaren als je om een of andere reden het artikel ooit terug wilt brengen.
spend_chapter_5_step_4_desc: Wacht een paar dagen. Vraag dan of je kind blij is of spijt heeft van de aankoop. Is er iets geleerd?
earn_chapter_5_intro: Er zijn veel banen. Hoe weet je wat je in de toekomst wilt gaan doen? Een eerste stap voor een kind op de lange reis om erachter te komen wat het wil is het kennismaken met al deze banen. In deze sessie daag jij je kind uit om te praten over banen die het ziet in de stad.
earn_chapter_5_desc: Ontdek banen in de stad, de eerste die er 10 ontdekt wint.
earn_chapter_5_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE Ask older children to spot jobs which have a common theme e.g. working with food - chef; baker, waiter etc. Ask them to do some research to find out what education and skills are required.
earn_chapter_5_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Know that there are a range of different jobs 
Understand working is one way we can earn money 
Appreciate that not all jobs pay the same
earn_chapter_5_step_1_desc: Ga naar het centrum of ergens anders waar je veel mensen aan het werk kunt zien.
earn_chapter_5_step_2_desc: Wie kan het eerst 10 banen benoemen op basis van de mensen die je ziet en de plekken waar je langs komt?
earn_chapter_5_step_3_desc: Heb je een baan ontdekt waarvan je kind denkt dat het dat in de toekomst zelf zou kunnen doen? Zoek uit welke opleiding en vaardigheden nodig zijn.
save_chapter_5_intro: Albert Einstein zei ooit 'Samengestelde rente is het achtste wereldwonder. Hij die het begrijpt krijgt het. Wie het niet begrijpt betaalt het.' Maar hoe gaan we het begrijpen? Deze sessie is een vervolg op de 'Introduceer rente' sessie. Maar nu ga je nog een stap verder door naar rente op rente te kijken.
save_chapter_5_desc: Leg samengestelde rente uit aan de hand van een paar kleine snoepjes.
save_chapter_5_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE May be suitable for some younger children with support.
save_chapter_5_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Understand the link between saving and earning interest 
Know that interest can make your money grow 
Appreciate that planning, spending and saving enables you to manage your money
save_chapter_5_step_1_desc: Geef je kind een snoepje en zeg: 'Eet dit het komende uur niet en je krijgt er nog één'.
save_chapter_5_step_2_desc: Leg uit dat rente krijgen hetzelfde is als nog een snoepje krijgen. Als je geld spaart dan krijg je meer.
save_chapter_5_step_3_desc: Zeg 'Eet de 2 snoepjes het volgende uur ook niet en je krijgt er 2 extra.
save_chapter_5_step_4_desc: Wat als je door blijft gaan? Hoeveel snoepjes heeft je kind na nog een uur (8)? Of over twee uur (16)?
save_chapter_5_step_5_desc: Leg uit dat samengestelde rente op dezelfde manier werkt. Je krijgt rente over wat je hebt gespaard en over de rente die je al hebt gekregen.
spend_chapter_6_intro: De eerste online aankoop is voor sommige kinderen soms beangstigend. Deze sessie is voor ouders die hun kind met hun eerste online aankoop met een kaart willen helpen.
spend_chapter_6_desc: Help je kind met de eerste online aankoop
spend_chapter_6_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE With younger children help them to buy something online – making the payment for them with your card.
spend_chapter_6_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Understand the importance of checking basic financial information e.g. receipts, card balances etc. 
Know that there are risks associated with shopping online 
Know things to look for to check if a website is safe to make an online purchase
spend_chapter_6_step_1_desc: Zorg ervoor dat je winkelt op een beveiligde webpagina. Controleer het slotje als je er niet zeker van bent.
spend_chapter_6_step_2_desc: Bereken het totale bedrag van de aankoop, zorg ervoor dat afleverkosten enz. er ook inzitten.
spend_chapter_6_step_3_desc: Leg uit dat er voldoende geld op de kaart moet staan om te kunnen betalen. Vraag je kind om het saldo te controleren.
spend_chapter_6_step_4_desc: Kies kaart als betalingsmethode en vul de vereiste gegegens in
spend_chapter_6_step_5_desc: Wacht een paar dagen nadat je het pakketje hebt ontvangen. Vraag je kind of de aankoop een succes was of dat het een spijtaankoop was.

PLZ_TRANSLATE This activity has helped your child learn:

What compound interest means

Planning what we do with our money
spend_chapter_1_on_completion:

The difference between needs and wants 
Making choices when spending money 
That their choices may be different to others
spend_chapter_2_on_completion:
PLZ_TRANSLATE This activity has helped your child learn: 
Planning and managing a simple budget 
Finding out how much some things cost 
Listening to other people’s ideas and opinions
spend_chapter_3_on_completion:
PLZ_TRANSLATE This activity has helped your child learn: 
Making comparisons between products 
Using information to make a spending decision 
Making spending choices based on their own needs
spend_chapter_4_on_completion:
PLZ_TRANSLATE This activity has helped your child learn: 
Making appropriate and environmentally consumer choices 
Making wise spending choices about what we need and want 
That people may make different choices about how they spend their money
spend_chapter_5_on_completion:
PLZ_TRANSLATE This activity has helped your child learn: 
Using a card to make a payment 
Keeping track of what they’ve spent or what they have 
Keeping their money and personal information safe
spend_chapter_6_on_completion:
PLZ_TRANSLATE This activity has helped your child learn: 
Using a card to make an online payment 
Things to look for to ensure a website is safe and secure 
Keeping their money and personal information safe
earn_chapter_1_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by discussing ways in which your children might earn money by doing small jobs for neighbours or other family members.
earn_chapter_2_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by setting an earnings goal – perhaps something they are saving up for. They could try out different products or offer a service e.g. car cleaning.  Alternatively, you could use the general idea to raise funds for a charity or school event.
earn_chapter_3_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by asking your child to think of something they want and researching how much it would cost to buy brand new or second hand – which would they chose to buy and why?
earn_chapter_4_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by encouraging the development of generic skills such as calculating and giving change. Talk about the skills and knowledge you need for the job you do. Carry out some research to find out what skills family members need for the jobs they do.
earn_chapter_5_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by thinking of similar jobs. What do they think is the hardest or most difficult job to do and why? Think about how jobs have changed – what was working like in the past, which jobs do we have now that weren’t available in the past?
save_chapter_1_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by seeing how much interest they would earn across 12 months.
save_chapter_2_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by giving up something else or continuing to cut back and save for a new goal. Each family member could have their own ‘cut back’ challenge – who can save the most in a given number of weeks.
save_chapter_3_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by testing out other products e.g. yoghurts or premium biscuits.
save_chapter_4_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by making it a family challenge, or to identify and prioritise the family’s needs and wants.
save_chapter_5_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by comparing  interest rates in adverts for savings accounts. Use an online savings calculator to experiment with interest rates and show what happens to your money over a few years.
spend_chapter_1_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by creating a ‘Wants’ list – each time your child says they ‘want’ something they add it to the list. At the end of the month go through the list and see how many things they still really want.
spend_chapter_2_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by planning a different type of activity – perhaps one with a slightly bigger budget. Set a savings goal for each family member to help achieve the activity.
spend_chapter_3_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by using the format to decide on other purchases. The bigger the purchase the more important it is to make sure you’ve made the right decision. Use consumer reviews to help make an inform decision.
spend_chapter_4_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by encouraging other family and friends to take up the challenge. Find out more about local recycling and find new ways to make sustainable decisions.
spend_chapter_5_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by checking their Gimi account so they can cross reference the receipts they have against the deductions.
spend_chapter_6_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by writing a list of items and using online shopping comparison sites to compare prices. Is it cheaper online or in a shop?  Don’t forget to take delivery costs into account.
earn_chapter_1_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Some household chores are just about living together as a family and this is a discussion to be had with your children. Keeping their rooms tidy or helping in general might be something that everyone in the family just does. Ask the question ‘should pocket money cover chores in general or should children be paid for the specific jobs they do?
earn_chapter_1_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Make sure the solution to the problems are suitable for the child’s age and can be completed safely. Maybe it’s best if you help?
earn_chapter_1_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Which chores deserve rewards and how much is up to you, but for this activity you need to make it clear that there will be a reward.
earn_chapter_1_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Consider making this a recurring activity, maybe the flowers need water next week as well? Can your child do the washing up every Thursday?
earn_chapter_2_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Running a business means knowing what you need, what your costs are and how much you are going to be able to sell your products for. Help your child work out these costs before they begin. Don’t forget to include the cost of electricity or gas for baking the cookies.
earn_chapter_2_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Talk to your child about advertising, promotions and product information. Why is it important? Without these your customers won’t know about a product. How much should they sell their cookies for? It needs to be more than the total cost of making them otherwise they won’t make any money.
earn_chapter_2_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Keep accurate financial records, so you know your costs (money spent), how many cookies were sold (sales) and your takings (money made selling the cookies).
earn_chapter_2_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Help your child understand how to work out your profit or loss – subtract costs from takings and you’ll know how much you’ve made.
earn_chapter_2_step_5_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Involve the child in the deposit process. Show them how it is done and what it looks like on your end.
earn_chapter_3_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Talk with your child about the things they need and those they just want. For instance, it wouldn’t be a good idea to sell things they still need and use e.g. a favourite toy. Look for things that they haven’t played with or used for a while. Discuss the condition of the items, will anyone want them if they are broken? Broken items should be recycled or repaired if possible.
earn_chapter_3_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Discuss the value of the items, remember in most cases second hand items will be worth less than you paid for them. Agree a price for each one, you may not get the price you want, but it is useful to talk about how much things are worth.
earn_chapter_3_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Reflect on how much everything would have cost when it was new. Was it worth it given what you sold it for? Discuss the importance of thinking carefully before you buy something, do you really need it? Highlight that buying second hand can sometimes be better value for money.
earn_chapter_4_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE You may need to help them break the list down into smaller tasks or individual skills, e.g. learning how to use a kitchen knife. Be realistic with them in terms of skills they can learn to do at this stage, e.g. you wouldn’t want them to be cutting hair or practicing open heart surgery!
earn_chapter_4_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Learning new skills is always a great idea. But exercise caution – it’s great if the job they want to do is very practical. However, if the job requires lots of new knowledge and understanding your child could identify new ideas they’d like to learn about instead or simply a task.  For example, for a doctor perhaps they can learn some simple first aid.
earn_chapter_4_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Some skills are harder to practise than others. Sometimes, the best practise consists of joining in and taking part where you or another adult is the expert. Can your child accompany you when you put on a band aid on a sibling? Or help you read the recipe when you are baking?
earn_chapter_5_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE You’ll need to go somewhere to find a good range of jobs on show. You might need to visit more than one place e.g. a busy town centre, a shopping centre, a tourist area etc.
earn_chapter_5_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE You could offer up a small prize for the first one to spot 10.
earn_chapter_5_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Make sure you talk to your child about the jobs you see being done. Ideas to prompt discussion - how vital do they think the job is and what might happen if that job wasn’t done; how much do they think it might pay; what would happen if no-one worked?
save_chapter_1_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Use a snack that they really like to eat e.g. dried or fresh fruit, crackers … anything healthy! The idea is to make resisting eating it immediately quite difficult for them, just as saving our money can be!
save_chapter_1_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Interest is when we are rewarded for saving what we already have – so another snack for not eating the one you have already, or a little bit of extra money for not spending the money we have saved.
save_chapter_1_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Use monetary examples to illustrate how it works in real life. It will help to make the interest level much higher than it is in real life so that it both encourages children and makes it obvious that they are ‘earning more money on their savings.
save_chapter_2_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Try to keep it simple, find something that you can do after just a few weeks saving to start with. If things don’t go as plan don’t give up, review and reflect and start again.
save_chapter_2_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Each member of the family might cut back on a different thing e.g. it might be the ice-cream at the park each week or walking instead of taking the bus.
save_chapter_2_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE You could keep a star chart for younger children, each time they cut back (save) then they can stick a star on the chart. Remember, it might be little amounts of money they save each time, but it all adds up.
save_chapter_3_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Visit a supermarket and look at the range of toilet paper on sale. Use the shelf-edge markers to compare prices, use the price per 100 sheets to help you. Identify which brand is the most expensive and which is the cheapest.  How much difference is there in price? Is the cheapest one an ‘own brand’ or supermarket version?  What about the most expensive?
save_chapter_3_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Set some sheets of the expensive toilet paper aside so that you can use it to compare next to the cheaper toilet paper later.
save_chapter_3_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE This time set some sheets of the cheaper toilet paper aside so that you can use it to compare next to the expensive toilet paper later.
save_chapter_3_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Create a chart to record your information on e.g. brand, price, number of sheets in a roll etc. Once you’ve calculated how much each type will cost compare it with how much your household currently spends. Which is the cheapest?
save_chapter_3_step_5_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE This is not just about the price but about value for money – so is the quality worth paying the extra money? Ask each member of the family which toilet paper they preferred and why.  Remember expensive is not always best however it is only worth buying cheaper if people are going to use it!
save_chapter_4_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Talk about why they can’t afford them now. Are the things they want to buy needs or wants? Make sure they understand the difference. Wants are usually the nice things to have but we don’t need them to survive.
save_chapter_4_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Why might the things they dream of be wants? Share your own list of needs and wants to help them understand that we must put needs before wants. Explain that we can’t always have everything we want, and that being able to sort out which is the most important to us is a very useful way of making choices. Try and keep expectations of what is realistic – this is about them saving up for ‘a dream’ so it needs to be achievable
save_chapter_4_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE You might need to help them think about what things cost. Discuss buying second-hand to reduce the cost.
save_chapter_4_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Talk about why it’s ok to change our minds about what we want, that sometimes things change, and we might need to adapt our choices. E.g. they might want a new football but then the friend they play football with moves away, so they’d rather have a scooter.
save_chapter_4_step_5_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Discuss how long it will take for the child to achieve their goal based on their current allowance. Look at ways to cut the time down, can they do added chores or save more?
save_chapter_5_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Remember the idea is to make resisting eating the snack immediately quite difficult for them, just as saving our money can be! So, use a snack that they really like to eat e.g. dried or fresh fruit, crackers … anything healthy!
save_chapter_5_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Interest is when we are rewarded for saving what we already have – so another snack for not eating the one you have already, or a little bit of extra money for not spending the money we have saved.
save_chapter_5_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Explain that this time you’ll get two extra treats because they’ve ‘saved’ the two they already have – in other words the more you save the more interest you’ll earn.
save_chapter_5_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Help them work out how many sweets they could have in another hour (eight); or in two hours (sixteen).
save_chapter_5_step_5_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Explain that savings accounts don’t double your money in this way but adding the interest to your savings will earn you more interest over time.
spend_chapter_1_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Look in the cupboards and decide what you are short of or discuss what might you need in order to make a meal that day? You might want to add a few things that aren’t absolutely essential so that you can prompt a discussion needs and wants.
spend_chapter_1_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Talk to your child about the items on the list. Are the things they want to buy needs or wants? Make sure they understand the difference. Wants are usually the nice things to have but we don’t need them to survive.
spend_chapter_1_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Discuss if they think its ok to have wants as well as needs? How might their wants differ from others? This could be a family discussion about family needs, but you could also think more widely such as what children in developing countries might need and want.
spend_chapter_1_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Whilst you are out shopping make a note of anything that your child asks for as an extra – are these needs and wants. Did you put anything ‘extra’ in your basket or did you manage to stick to the list? Why might prioritising in this way help us to save money?
spend_chapter_2_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE To start with allow ideas to be free flowing, part of this activity is to give them an awareness of how much things actually cost, so they may come up with ideas that are simply going to be to expensive but they need to find this out.
spend_chapter_2_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Support your child to find out how much everything will cost – use the internet and local information. You will need to create a spreadsheet to record the costs of each item.
spend_chapter_2_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Ideally some of the activities will fit the budget whilst others may bust it. As the aim is to do something within budget this will either narrow the choice or you could look at ways to reduce the cost so that an activity idea can be brought into budget. E.g. you could take sandwiches instead of buying lunch etc. Or look for money off vouchers/coupons.
spend_chapter_2_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Put your child in charge of collecting the receipts on the day. Check each one against your planned spend on the spreadsheet. Talk about why things might have cost more than planned or less than planned. How could they bring things in on budget next time?
spend_chapter_3_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE This needs to be a realistic activity, so feel free to adapt to other items of clothing or equipment.
spend_chapter_3_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Other things to think about depending on the product might be ‘fit for purpose’ (does it do what you need it to do); strength; durability; guarantee etc. There is no point in looking for school shoes and buying a pair of trainers if you aren’t allowed to wear trainers to school.
spend_chapter_3_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE The differences can be very subtle – so allow time for your child to try on shoes more than once. Use prompts such as how well do they fit, do they feel comfortable, are they easy to get on and off, are they warmer, cooler. Think about other issues such as how easy will they be able to keep clean, can they be used in different situations e.g. for school and for playing in the park, are you paying for features you might not need or want e.g. flashing lights or detachable bows?
spend_chapter_3_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE You might want to give each pair of shoes a ranking e.g. 7 out of 10 to help the final decision. The most expensive might not automatically be the best, equally cheapest can sometimes be a false economy if they aren’t as well-made, they may not last as long. Remember sometimes we pay more for a branded product or for product that carries a fashionable logo – this probably won’t make it any better in terms of quality just more desirable.
spend_chapter_4_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Make a chart to record your ideas. List the things you are going to cut back on – it might help to look in the cupboards and fridge to find the things that have been lurking there for ages … these are things that you don’t use. Think about needs and wants too – perhaps we buy things just because we want them rather than needing them, or thinking of other ways we could do things e.g. using plastic tubs instead of cling film?
spend_chapter_4_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Are there substitutes you could make? Could you buy in bulk and refill bottles of cleaning solution or washing liquid? What about water bottles or other plastic containers can your re-purpose items? Record your ideas on the chart.
spend_chapter_4_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Check out your rubbish bin – are there items in it which could be recycled? Do you choose products because the container can be recycled? E.g. crisps are often sold in packs or tubes that are not recyclable, this maybe one product you make a point of making sure can be recycled. Add your ideas to your chart. Look up what can be recycled in your local area, make sure you recognise the recyclable logos.
spend_chapter_4_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Use your chart to craft your agreement – are you going to accept responsibility for everything or will some of the family be responsible for certain elements of it. E.g. your child could be a recycling monitor or checker.”
spend_chapter_5_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Explain that they need to keep the password they use to log onto their Gimi account safe, they shouldn’t share it with anyone. They can only spend what they have on the card – so if the balance (the money that is available) is not enough they won’t be able to make the purchase.
spend_chapter_5_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE The PIN is their personal code number linked to their card, again this is ‘top secret’ information and they shouldn’t tell anyone what their number is.”
spend_chapter_5_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Receipts are also a useful way of keeping track of the money they’ve spent as well as proof of purchase should they need to return an item. Once they have paid make sure they put their card away safely in a wallet , together with the receipt.  Explain that it is their responsibility to make sure their Gimi Card is kept safe.
spend_chapter_5_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE This reflection is about thinking carefully before we buy – do we really need it; do we just want it; Will we still feel the same about the item in a few days or a few weeks – do we still want it? Was it worth the money?
spend_chapter_6_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Show your child how to look for the padlock sign next to the URL address – this means the website is encrypted and personal information kept secure e.g. card number and CV number.
spend_chapter_6_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Delivery fees are often added at the last minute, so check at the beginning to see if delivery is free or not. Delivery fees can often make an item more expensive than buying in the shops, so it is worth considering this before the actual purchase is made.
spend_chapter_6_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Explain that they need to keep the password they use to log onto their Gimi account safe, they shouldn’t share it with anyone. They can only spend what they have on the card – so if the balance (the money that is available) is not enough they won’t be able to make the purchase.
spend_chapter_6_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE It is good practice to check the numbers again before you click ‘buy’, just to make sure you’ve correctly entered them. Also, check email and delivery address information so that you can be sure you will get a receipt and that the item will be delivered to the correct address.
spend_chapter_6_step_5_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE This reflection is about thinking carefully before we buy – do we really need it; do we just want it; Will we still feel the same about the item in a few days or a few weeks – do we still want it? Was it worth the money? You could ask them what they might do differently next time. With purchases made online we have 14 days to return things if we change our minds, but we may have to pay the delivery costs, so it is still worth trying to be really sure we want the item before we buy.
earn_chapter_6_intro: PLZ_TRANSLATE Money plays an important role in our lives and understanding the importance of working and earning is vital. In this session you will create a fun game which will challenge your child to think about a range of different jobs and the potential salaries, skills and qualifications needed to do those jobs.
earn_chapter_6_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Find out about a range of different jobs and create a fun game to play.
earn_chapter_6_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE Younger children could participate with support, and certainly play the game at the end. This activity could link to Interests and skills (earning activity 6) and Job spotting (earning activity 1).
earn_chapter_6_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Know that money and earnings is one factor to consider when choosing a job 
Understand the reasons why some jobs pay more than others 
Appreciate that different jobs need different skills and qualifications
earn_chapter_6_on_completion:
PLZ_TRANSLATE This activity has helped your child make links between work and earning money including: 
Issues to consider when choosing a job 
Potential salaries and earnings 
Developing skills and the importance of qualifications
earn_chapter_6_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Find out more about jobs which particularly attract them. Talk to other family members about what sort of jobs they do and what it entails.
earn_chapter_6_step_1_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE With your child create a list of different jobs e.g. doctor, shop assistant, hairdresser, lawyer, charity worker - try to think of as many as you can, up to 30 if possible.
earn_chapter_6_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Try to get a broad range of jobs, some which pay highly as well as some low paid; those which are highly skilled and those which are less skilled etc. Use the internet to find out about salaries; qualifications etc.
earn_chapter_6_step_2_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Decide on 5 or 6 different categories to rank each job against e.g. salary; skills; qualifications; hours worked; education; importance to society; helping people
earn_chapter_6_step_3_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Now get creative, create a card for each job. Start with a picture of the worker, you can use photos from magazines or draw your own. Write a short paragraph about the job.
earn_chapter_6_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE You can work together to rank the different jobs, try putting them into order for each category and then allocate the points to each one.  Re-sort for the next category and repeat. Talk with your child about the different jobs, why do they think some earn more than others, or need more qualifications.
earn_chapter_6_step_4_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Use your chosen categories and give each job a rank! Now play the game – who will win and come out on top?
earn_chapter_6_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Play the game with 2 – 4 players, deal out an even number of cards to each player, these should be in a face down pile. Player on the left of dealer starts and looks at their top card and selects which category they are going to compete in, e.g. qualifications, read out their score and then the remaining players read out their score in that category, the player with the highest score wins and takes all the cards from that round. They then begin the next round. The player who manages to collect all the cards wins the game.
earn_chapter_6_step_5_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Talk to your child about which jobs they think they would prefer to do? Why? What might they need to think about if they really want to do that job?
earn_chapter_6_step_5_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE This is about encouraging aspirations, so that your child feels that they can work towards gaining the right qualifications or skills to do a job that will give them satisfaction. The choices they make about work and money will affect their life.
save_chapter_6_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Keep your money safe, learn how to keep track of the money you have and what you’ve spent.
save_chapter_6_intro: PLZ_TRANSLATE Knowing how much money you have and what you need to spend it on makes managing your money much easier. Keeping tabs on your money is a great way to help you make the most of it. In this session you will support your child to learn how to keep track of their spending and saving.
save_chapter_6_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE For younger children practice counting cash in their moneybox or draw a chart that shows how much money they have in their Gimi account or other savings account. Older children could create a simple budget sheet to show the things they regularly spend money on.
save_chapter_6_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Know some different ways to keep track of their money 
Appreciate why it is important to keep money safe  
Be able to plan and track their saving and spending
save_chapter_6_step_1_title: PLZ_TRANSLATE Know how much you’ve got
save_chapter_6_step_1_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE How do they know how much money they have – ask them to check their Gimi account to get a balance and count the cash they have – what’s the total (balance)?
save_chapter_6_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Talk about where your child keeps their money, this may be in several places, e.g. Gimi App; cash in the house; other savings accounts etc. Knowing how much money you have is important, as it allows you to make plans about what you have to spend, plans about saving up for something important and to know if you can afford to buy something when you want.
save_chapter_6_step_2_title: PLZ_TRANSLATE Know what you’ve got coming in
save_chapter_6_step_2_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Check their Gimi account to make sure pocket money or earnings for chores has gone in. How can they tell? Look at the information recorded on their Gimi account – what does it tell them about the money going into their account?
save_chapter_6_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Discuss with your child why it’s also important to know how much money you have coming in?  Knowing how much money they already have and how much more money they will have in the next week or month will allow them to plan any spending requirements they may have, e.g. birthday present or an activity they want to do.
save_chapter_6_step_3_title: PLZ_TRANSLATE Keep a note of spending
save_chapter_6_step_3_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE How do they know what they’ve spent? It’s easy if they are using cash, as the money in the wallet diminishes, but if they use their card it’s harder to see. Check the balance in the Gimi app and check receipts against deductions.
save_chapter_6_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Make sure they always keep receipts for things they buy and that they cross reference deductions against the receipts.  Keep receipts in a safe place in case you need to return an item.
save_chapter_6_step_4_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE No one wants to lose their money. Talk with your child about how they can keep their money safe. Plan what will they do with their wallet when they go out shopping; what will they do with receipts and where will they keep their money or card in the house?
save_chapter_6_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Learning to keep our money safe is very important, share ideas about how you keep your money safe.  If they have a Gimi or other cash card you can reinforce the importance of not sharing their PIN number.  If they lose their card, then it is very important they report it immediately.
save_chapter_6_on_completion:
PLZ_TRANSLATE This activity has helped your child learn about how to manage their money and keep it safe including: 
Ways to track their money 
The importance of keeping their money safe
Plan and track their spending and saving
save_chapter_6_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by planning for a long-term goal e.g. a trip away; or an activity with friends, how much will they have to earn/save in order to achieve their goal in 6 months or 12 months.
spend_chapter_7_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Make simple cash purchases working out coins to use and change to receive.
spend_chapter_7_intro: PLZ_TRANSLATE Learning to manage money is a vital skill for young children recognising and understanding the value of the coins and notes we use is the start of learning this skill. This session introduces children to using coins to make simple purchases, together you will choose something to buy, select coins with which to make the purchase and working out the change needed and then checking it.
spend_chapter_7_age_adaption: PLZ_TRANSLATE For older children introduce using notes as well as coins.
spend_chapter_7_learning_outcome:
PLZ_TRANSLATE After this activity your child will: 
Recognise and choose the correct value coins 
Know the importance of checking change 
Understand that we need to pay from items we buy
spend_chapter_7_step_1_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Empty your purse or pocket and with your child look at the different coins, line them up in order of value.
spend_chapter_7_step_1_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Very young children might line them up in order of size, as they think the bigger the coin must be best! Start with just the 1 and 2 pence pieces and then add in the 5p; 10p and 20p.  It will help if you have lots of pennies, so that you can explain that the 2p = 2 x 1p etc.
spend_chapter_7_step_2_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Select some small items and write some simple price labels. Give your child some coins and ask them to select the coins that they will need to buy an item.
spend_chapter_7_step_2_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Start simple, price items at no more than 10p, make sure you have some prices where they will need to use more than one coin to make a ‘purchase’.
spend_chapter_7_step_3_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Explain that sometimes we don’t always have the exact coins to pay for something and we must give a coin that is more than the price, when we do this, we need change. Play again and encourage paying with larger value coins, and to work out how much change they need.
spend_chapter_7_step_3_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE This may take a lot of practice.  Use lots of pennies to help explain. You could play a board game such as ‘Pop to the Shops’ or ‘Buy it Right’ which teach about paying and receiving change. Practice counting and adding when doing things around the house e.g. how many spoons in the drawer; 5 socks plus 5 socks equals 10 socks etc. Next step is to practice counting in 5’s or 10’s
spend_chapter_7_step_4_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Take a trip to the shops to buy something simple and low value e.g. a banana or an apple, allow your child to pay for the item. Which coins will they need to use to pay for it? Will they need change, can they work out the change?
spend_chapter_7_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Let your child take control, it requires patience, so this is not an activity to do when you are in a hurry. The more you practice at home the easier and quicker it will become for them.
spend_chapter_7_on_completion:
PLZ_TRANSLATE This activity has helped your child learn about how to manage their money including: 
The value of coins 
Selecting the appropriate coins to make a purchase 
Calculating what change they will need to receive
spend_chapter_7_extra: PLZ_TRANSLATE Extend this activity by increasing the cost of the item purchased, introducing higher value coins and eventually notes
save_chapter_1_step_4_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Now work out how much money you will have if you keep £20 in your account for the next 6 months. ‘Payday’ comes once a month.
save_chapter_1_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE In order to reinforce understanding, add in some practice so that they can work it out for themselves and see how it might build up their savings.
save_chapter_2_step_4_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE Congratulations you’ve achieved your savings goal – did you miss the things you’d cut back on? Now enjoy your family activity!
save_chapter_2_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE Talk together about the process of cutting back and saving money. Did it take you longer to save than you’d thought it would? Would you do it again?  Can you think of other things you could cut back on to save even more?
earn_chapter_4_step_4_desc: PLZ_TRANSLATE What have they learnt? What would they do differently next time? Did they enjoy learning new skills or new things, if not why not?
earn_chapter_4_step_4_idea: PLZ_TRANSLATE What else might they need to learn? If they didn’t enjoy learning new skills in that area, why not and what might that mean in terms of a job in the future? Is there another area they might like to explore?  Explain that people can and do change jobs in adult life – nothing is set in stone and a key skill to have is to be adaptable and willing to try new things.
